awd_titl_txt: ATD:  Collaborative Research:  Multivariate Quantiles for Rapid Spatio-Temporal Threat Detection
awd_abstract_narration:
Different kinds of data on societal attributes, observed from multiple sources, at multiple locations, and at different points in time, will be studied in this project. The geometrical properties of such data will be analyzed to quantify and characterize normal patterns in the data, which will then be leveraged to identify sudden departures from normal patterns within societies. Methodology for understanding normal patterns in the data and rapidly detecting change in one or more aspects of the data will be devised in this project. Data from different locations around the world will be analyzed and used to formulate strategies for risk mitigation and emergency responses.

The geometric properties of high-dimensional spatio-temporal data will be studied in this project to construct a multi-dimensional extremity indicator. This indicator and other statistical and machine learning techniques will be used for rapid spatio-temporal change detection, under a variety of technical conditions and frameworks. Such changes may be towards specific known directions, or generic departures from normal patterns. Methods for detecting changes in extremes and tails of multivariate probability distributions will likewise be developed as part of this project. Social, economic, and supply chain logistics data will then be studied to develop policy and rapid response strategies using data-driven techniques.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-ATD has developed algorithms and data to advance spatio-temporal threat detection both generally and in ?big data? social science & supply chain contexts more specifically. It has illustrated these advancements through a wide range of applications, particularly in the area of political violence. Threat detection relates to scenarios involving rapid changes in multivariate spatio-temporal data. Such data has many underlying structures, and over time changes may happen in many ways, such as in the expected values of various variables, their dependency relations, their spatial dependency patterns, trends or other secular temporal components, and especially importantly, in the tails and extremes of their joint distributions.

We have advanced algorithms for the rapid detection of such structural and systems changes in this context, especially when the changes may be small in their effects, so as not to be noticeable in routine monitoring and analysis. We have also collected and fused new and existing social science datasets for these endeavors and have in turn studied the properties of these data with a wide variety of new and established statistical methodologies.

The above efforts contributed to the development of a very clean, usable algorithm for simultaneous model selection and inference in a framework that encompasses much of classical statistics. We have extensively demonstrated this algorithm?s applicability in both simulations and in applied big data social science contexts. Considering the latter application area, we have demonstrated that our algorithm offers a number of improvements over existing threat detection tools. Above and beyond out-of-sample improvements in classification accuracy and related metrics, our algorithm makes several unique and notable contributions in the area of ?machine informed? science and algorithms for threat detection. Such contributions are likely to be of special interest among machine learning researchers and social scientists concerned with ?interpretable machine learning? and ?machine learning for scientific discovery,? as opposed to the development and/or use of black box prediction methods.

To support these endeavors, the multi-disciplinary team members as part of this project have now published a wide range of novel data, measurement, and algorithmic innovations across multiple application domains such as political violence or supply chain analysis. A set of (published or accepted) achievements associated with the University of Delaware component of this award appear below.

1. The development and/or application of new algorithms and statistical methods for analyses of political violence survival (time to event) data (Bagozzi et al. 2019; Anderson, Bagozzi and Koren 2021).

2. Innovations in the spatio-temporal measurement and analysis of political violence in contexts employing big data derived from Twitter, international newswire reports, and/or additional secondary sources (Koren, Bagozzi, and Benson 2021; Bagozzi, Berliner, and Welch 2021).

3. Innovations in the supervised coding, and subsequent statistical modeling, of access to information request data, including advancements in multi-label classification, time series-based anomaly detection, and social science theory testing (Erlich et al. 2021; Erlich et al. Forthcoming).
